item.description: Simple wild-west themed spin and move game. Game includes 12x12 cardboard game board, spinner & 5 wooden discs for pawns.
Simple roll and move game that has the theme of Doc Holliday going after the "bandits."

A set collection game in which players' melds earn them money. Cash can be used to draw more cards and to neutralize or steal opponents' melds. Players may extend or protect their own melds. Most money at the end wins.

The game is played with two or three ordinary decks of playing cards.

This game can be played in various formations. One game is played like Memory with players turning over tiles to find matching numbers. Another game has players rolling dice and selecting tiles that match the total and then filling up a player mat.

Translation of description from speldatabase.be
Six large boards each contain 10 drawings. Each time the sequence of numbers from 1 to 10 visually presented. Each card has its own theme. All 60 illustrations are also at much separate tickets.

The rulebook suggests many different ways to use this material.

As a warm-up, each player gets a playmat. The legkaartjes be dealt on the table and each player is trying to quickly collect ten cards.

Later, a lottery game played which also drawing upon the memory. The legkaartjes now lie face down in the middle. On his turn, each player now looking for tickets that fit with the player's mat.

The box also contains two regular dice. That you can use the right cards to collect. After looking dice each player a card with the same figure.

Each player who wins all ten cards can collect.

The illustrations are today but what about old fashioned charm because of their simple charm. Young children look really illustrations bearing the requisite number image is. The many game modes make this game more than once can be used.

Apparently a different game from the same-titled Erstes Rechnen.
Laita is a game of tactics played on an irregular 4x5 diamond board. It can be played by two, three or four individual players, or by four players in a partnership game.

Four Square (4²) is a tactical game that can expand from one board to many, and where the playing area can wax and wane and twist and turn.

It is available as 2 or 4 boards, with the unique option of add-on boards. A total of 6 different boards are available.

Chiaroscuro is an advanced version of Fleur Designs' game "t'other" for 2, 3 or 4 players. Most of Fleur's games have simple rules - the interest is in the tactics - and although Chiaroscuro's rules are, like the others, short they are more complex and need the ultimate in concentration.

Your task is simple if you've placed your pieces well. But can you keep track of your opponents?

t'other is a simple strategy game and was designed with a modern Wars of the Roses in mind. It's not possible to explain without giving the full rules but those not from either side of the Pennines will be relieved to know that even southerners and foreigners will be capable of playing the game and no phrase book is required!

[From publisher:] The visitors of the Beach Stadium all look agog with expectation at Twiddle Turtle: Will she be the best again at rolling, skittling, and playing boule in the 2222 Olympics? A potentially record-breaking game collection with game board printed on both sides.

Can be combined with: Schildi SchildkrÃ¶te

item.description:
Spin, count and match! Children build counting skills for numbers 1-10 while learning about insects. Spin the numbered bug wheel. The first player to cover three leaves with bugs in a row, wins!

Includes four laminated game cards with fun bug facts on the back, spinner and 36 markers. For 2-4 players.

Lunge, dodge and attack in a head-to-head battle between two mighty foes.

Tail controllers enable full control over the action
Built-in sensors keep score
Powerful roaring sound effects
Articulated dinosaur action
Realistic prehistoric landscape
Step back in time as dueling dinos roar, snarl and battle each other. Just grab the tail controller and challenge a friend to see which dinosaur rules.

"The classic game of Bingo has a new twist with Dora and all of her friends. Kids and adults will enjoy this Bingo Adventure!"

Dora Bingo is classic bingo, but without the numbers and letters. Instead, colors and pictures of the Dora characters identify each spot, and a spinner is used to call out the spaces. Red Swiper, blue Boots, orange Dora, etc. Simple enough for four-year-olds. Game includes four cards and a spinner, and can be stretched to five players if one calls out the spots while the other four play.

Note that this game includes small plastic disks to cover the spaces, which could pose a choking hazard to very small children -- clearly marked on the package.

Ages 4 and up

name.value: Sesame Street Preschool Games for Growing-Shapes

item.description:
From the box: "Each GAMES FOR GROWING game set contains a variety of game materials that are used in various combinations depending on the particular game played.
Games for Growing-Shapes has instructions for 8 possible games.
Game 1 Shape Pair Game, object is to collect the most pairs of shape cards before opponents.
Game 2 Remember-A-Shape Game, object is to collect most pairs of shapes by remembering where they are. 
Game 3 Spin-A-Shape Game. object is to get rid of your cards by matching the spinner.
Game 4 Fish for Shapes Game, object is to collect the most pairs of shape cards by going "fishing."
Game 5 Shape Rummy, object is to get rid of your cards in your hand before any other players by grouping shapes into sets. 
Game 6 The Funny Train Game, object is to complete a train of three of the same shapes or five different shapes.
Game 7 Sherlocks's Great Shape Mystery Game, object is to collect the most cards by matching mystery cards with cards in your hand.
Game 8 Mumford's Hiding Shapes Game, object is to Collect the most cards that make pictures by finding the hidden shapes in the picture.

World Bank: The Game casts players as governments of developing countries. The goal of the game is to acquire resources of various kinds, dealing with debt, foreign aid, multinational cartels and natural events in the process.

While the game involves rolling and moving around a circular board, there are a number of subtleties; players may trade amongst themselves, establish cartels for uncommon resources, and even engage in wars.
Krikos uses (circular) Byzantine Chess board, colours it as modern chess, uses modern chess pieces and moves and an additional set of new rules.

Hex Agon is an abstract strategy game that can be played for different ways, including versions that allow for solitaire play and for up to six players to play. Mechanics involve racing of pieces, capturing of pieces, and placement strategy.
Simple roll and move game. Game came with a game board, 4 Blue Horse pegs, 4 Green Horse pegs, 4 Red Horse Pegs and 4 Yellow Horse pegs and a die for movement

Players take part in the stag rut on a Scottish island. Each player plays a stag interested in food, fighting and, of course, the opposite sex. The object of the game is to be the stag who has kissed the most doeples and outperformed rivals in head-to-head combat!

Who will finish as the dominant stag ?

The game is medium-lightweight and comes with a quick start-up guide to allow easy play. It is deep enough to offer meaningful decisions and challenges to gamers while still being accessible to non-gamers.

Fragor's Essen release for 2007.

name.value: Show Business: The New Game from Emile Littler
Show Business: Emile Littler's New Game

item.description:
The Littlers - Emile, Prince & their sister Blanche were at one time the most powerful figures in the theatrical world of the West End & Provincial theater, with almost a total monopoly in producing musicals & pantomime in the UK.

This game was designed by Emile & was intended to give an interesting insight into the numerous hazards to the pursuit of stardom.

Players, starting from the Village Choir, would throw the dice & proceed along the track towards the School of Dramatic Art obeying the various directions on the way.

The correct number required must be thrown to finish on Stardom & the first player to reach here wins the game.

Amongst others Emile Littler was responsible for putting the young Radio & Variety star, Julie Andrews, into his pantomimes as the Princess in 'Aladdin' & this game is a delightfully produced & highly collectible period piece.

name.value: Big Brain Academy: Juego de Mesa

item.description:
From the Publisher:

Which team has the biggest brain? The new mental fitness game based on the original best-selling Nintendo™ DS title. Speed and accuracy count - not smarts - when answering questions at the Big Brain Academy. Challenge your brain in five fun categories: Analyze, Compute, Identify, Memorize and Think. Teams collect chips based on the number of questions they answer correctly. Big Brain Academy keeps minds nimble and players laughing! Your team's goal is to collect the most chips. Game includes 330 cards, dry erase pen, puzzle pieces, red revealer, sand timer, scale, scoring chips and spinner. 2 to 6 Players. Ages 8 and up.

item.description:
Renaissance Warfare was third in the SAGA series of rulebooks for period warfare. It is a set of miniatures rules simulating land warfare in Europe and Asia from 1494 to 1690. It may be used with any scale of figures. There are extensive rules for organization but players may use figures based in the standard DBx format with little problem.

The rules contain rich detail on warfare in this period of many unit types while still providing a playable game that will see a result in a few hours. There are 49 army lists that themselves provide a rich source of information and cover the important armies of Asia as well as those of Europe. There are also lists for relatively minor powers such as two lists for Ireland and one for the Knights of St. John.

Cossack Wars is a set of miniatures rules designed to simulate small-scale warfare between cossacks of the 17th and 18th century. It is a skirmish-type wargame with individual figures representing single cossacks. They are given various personalized characteristics.

The rules are simple and perhaps somewhat reduced to produce quick play. The rule book also contains 13 prepared scenarios of various sizes of which the largest would require 180 figures (360 figures to also represent dismounted cossacks) and the smallest 30 (60).

Husaria is a set of miniatures rules designed to simulate land warfare in Eastern Europe during the period 1558-1699. Given the subject matter, there are many rule elements designed to convey the unique context of war in the East.

Each figure represents 60-100 men. The units are portrayed by stands of figures and represent what in the West during this period would have been brigade-sized groupings. There is a clever interactive system for players to build armies from detailed army lists for all the varied armies of this period: Polish Commonwealth, Cossacks, Tatars, Ottomans, Muscovites, Lithuanian, Swedes, etc.

There is also a very large list of leaders with micro bios as well as a listing of important battles from the period.

Cities! Busy Places, Friendly Faces is a game associated with the Kindermusik music education program, aimed at preschoolers. The game is actually a collection of several games, each with its own deck of cards and instructions. Most all of the games involve matching pictures on the cards with pictures on the board. In one game, "Busy City" for instance, one person selects a card, and then pantomimes the image or activity on the card for other players to guess.

item.description:
Free downloadable (Australian) trivia boardgame about environmentalism. Answer 10 points worth of questions about people, the environment and economics, then reach the sustainable Earth space to win.

The board and the question cards are provided. You will need to provide 2 six-sided dice and optionally, an egg timer.

From the editor's introduction:

In this book, Phil Barker (a founder member of the Wargames Research Group) sets out to introduce the fascinations of the period to the novitiate ancient wargamer. He describes not only the troop types, weapons and tactics of the period, but also shows how to begin amassing armies of wargame figures which are balanced in their composition, and how to use these same armies to win ancient battles on the tabletop using the Wargames Research Group Ancient Rules.

Black Hole Explorer is an interesting children's game about building a rocket to travel to and study a black hole. The game is designed to be light-hearted, educational and fun.

The game is played in three steps:

First construct your ship using what funds you have available -- $10 million to $60 million. Your ship must have probes, radiation shielding, gravitational strength and power to drive your spaceship.

And, don't forget to name your spaceship!

Next, travel to the black hole and enter into a low enough orbit with it to launch your probes.

There are spaces around the black hole to draw Event cards that may help or hinder your mission.

Finally, escape the black hole's gravity (which is harder than getting there), return to Earth and study the data from your probes. Did you gather enough information to win the Nobel Prize? The first player back gets to roll for the chance first. But is he or she fails, then the next finisher gets the chance.

The game has competitive and collaborative playing options, and also information for playing the game with large groups.

Basic Cowboys and Indians game from Crunchy Frog, part of the 'Big Damn' series of games. Includes cardboard cut-out figures, but can also be played with plastic Cowboy & Indian figures. Simple combat mechanic results in a quick, bloody battle; Basic game doesn't take terrain into effect so movement is based on an included 'ruler' which determines how far you can move. 5 pages of rules(including the optional rules), plus 5 scenarios.

Adapted from the inside dust jacket:

A wargamer's guide to classic battles and fighting men of ancient times is based upon a popular series which first appeared in the magazine Military Modeling. Charles Grant here describes in great detail the classic battles of ancient times, the men who fought them, their equipment and mode of fighting.

Adapted from the inside dust jacket:

"Wargame Tactics" will be welcomed by enthusiasts old and new, by Generals good, bad and downright indifferent. For it demonstrates that victory on the wargames table can be achieved (and usually is) by the player who adheres to the tactics of the period in question and to the basic principles of the art of war. It therefore follows that the player who studies the military background of his particular period will not only derive more enjoyment from his hobby, he will also win more battles.

Adapted from the inside dust jacket:

Solo-Wargaming caters for both the player who cannot find opponents, and the player who wants an additional fix between sessions with friends!

It describes innumerable methods of maneuvering two wargame armies under such conditions of secrecy and surprise that the result of the battle is in the balance until the last cannon is fired. It opens many doors to ingenious and practical methods of doing battle with model soldiers, raising the pastime in some sense almost to the level of chess.

Microbadge:

Expansion for Warmaster

Warmaster Armies by Rick Priestley was published in 2006 as an expansion and clarification for Warmaster, Games Workshop's 10-15mm fantasy miniatures game. This expansion gives 14 new, complete, and official army lists. These lists include updates on the races and nations included in the original Warmaster book, as well as making some lists that had appeared in various GW magazines "official." In making the step to being "official" it also shows they have been play-tested and are, for the most part, balanced. A brand new list, Araby, with magic carpets and genies, is also included.

This list is superior in its presentation of the individual army rules. Both army composition rules and rules for play, are boiled down to a single page for each race and nation. Each race's spells are also presented.

Armies included are:
Empire (human)
Tomb Kings (undead)
Chaos
Orc
High Elf
Dwarf
Skaven
Lizardman
Bretonnia (human)
Kislev (human)
Dark Elf
Vampire Count (undead)
Daemon
Araby

This book was made available for free as a downloadable pdf. It looks like GW originally planned to print it, based on the b/w interiors rather than color, but went the online route instead.

name.value: Sesame Street PreSchool Games for Growing: Going Places

item.description: This is an educational game that uses two different game boards for 2 different learning levels to teach children the concept of "going places," including methods of transportation and locations to travel to.

Free print-and-play game to teach children about the problems facing sea turtle survival.

Each player starts with 10 turtle tokens, and the game can end when any player increases his population to 50 tokens, or when after a set number of turns, the player who has the largest population. If a player runs out of turtle tokens, he is out of the game.

There are 4 variable conditions that help or hinder population growth. Each time a six is rolled on the dice, spin the spinner to see if these conditions (human interaction, climate, predators, and food availability) flip-flop from high to low or from low to high:

As players move around the board, cards may be drawn to collect or lose turtle tokens, change conditions, and gain tokens by answering trivia questions.

As players complete one life cycle and cross the start space, their turtle population increases based on the current population.

If players arrive at the same space at the same time, the turtles tussle producing more (baby) turtles for both players.

All components, except pawns and turtle tokens are available to download at the website: http://edweb.sdsu.edu/courses/edtec670/Cardboard/board/s/seaturtle/seaturtle.html
An educational game for children to help them learn the months of the year, and what event occur in each month.

Conni is having a birthday and all of her friends are invited. Come to the party with them!

Her mother has baked a delicious cake. Everyone wants a piece of it, but only those that have a place at the table with Conni can get a piece of cake.

The clock is set and it begins! This game requires observation and quick reactions.

Contents:

 A real clock with bell
 5 wooden dice
 1 sticker
 30 Birthday guests
 6 plates
 1 Birthday table
 1 Little-hippo chip
 Instructions





Conni hat Geburtstag und alle ihre Freunde sind eingeladen. Feiert mit !

Ihre Mama hate einen leckeren Kuchen gebacken. Alle wollen etwas davon haben, doch nur, wer einen Platz am Tisch mit Conni ergattert, bekommt ein Stück vom Kuchen ab.

Die Zeit-Uhr wird gestellt und los geht`s ! Bei diesem Spiel sind genaues Schauen und eine schnelle Reaktion gefragt !

Inhalt: 

 1 echte Zeituhr mit Kuchendruck
 5 Holzwürfel
 1 Aufkleberbogen
 30 Geburtstagsgäste
 6 Krümel-Teller
 1 Geburtstagstisch
 1 Seepferdchen-Chip
 1 Anleitung

A two player trick taking game in which the objective is to go out first with a two- or one-suited hand of nine cards. Players start with nine randomly dealt cards and two face down "shed" cards between them. Standard no-trump trick-taking rules apply (with aces high) and the loser of the trick exchanges two of his cards (without revealing them) for the two face down cards.

From Games of Art, Springer is a game based on the artwork of Ferdinand Springer.

The object of the game is to connect all four sides and claim at least a minimum number of points by filling in spaces on the board. Play is restricted not allowing you to fill in a space that shares a side with a space of your color already filled in.

name.value: The Oxford History of Board Games

item.description:
"The Oxford History of Board Games investigates the principles of board games throughout the ages and across the world, exploring the fascinating similarities and differences that give each its unique appeal, and drawing out the significance of game-playing as a central part of human experience - as vital to a culture as its music, dance, and tales."

"Beautifully illustrated, and with diagrams to show the finer points of the games, this is a fascinating and accessible guide to a richly rewarding subject"

756 Red Apple Cards 
252 Green Apple Cards

Part of the Apples to Apples Series.

item.description: A three-player trick taking game in which each player gains control of an exposed dummy after winning a trick. The trump suit for the hand changes depending on which player controls the dummy.

Spyhunting is a 2-player strategy game whereby one player acts as the hunter and one player is hunted a.k.a. the spy.

This game can be played with standard equipment (checkerboard) from the average gamer collection in addition to some non-standard dice.

The spy’s objective is to travel from one corner to the opposite corner and back without being “shot.” The hunter’s objective is to “shoot” the spy before he or she accomplishes his or her objective.

This game was a Top 11 finalist in the 2002 Board Game Design Competition called "Simultaneous Action Design" awarded by About.Com.

Odds and Evens is a 2-player strategy game that can be played with components found in the average gamer collection.

The object of the game is to be the first player to move all of your pieces to the opponent's home row.

Players take turns rolling two six-sided dice and moving pawns on a standard checkerboard. A unique rule to the game completely eliminates any advantage earned of one player rolling better dice combinations.

From the Rules: THE LUCK O' THE IRISH is the game for Kings of Ireland, Leprechauns, Fairies, and the Little Folk. It is played by means of pieces being moved around the playing board, Ireland, according to throw of the dice.

The players set off from Dublin taking any road they wish and on their journey around Ireland must collect a Pot of Gold, a Harp, a Shamrock, a Shillelagh, and an Emerald. The first player to return to Dublin with all five items is the winner.

On their journey player will visit the historical cities of Ireland , cross the River Shannon, find their Pot of Gold at the end of the Rainbow, ride in the Jaunting Car and encounter that mischievous elf of Irish folk-lore the Leprechaun.

But beware there are pitfalls of which the most ferocious is the Banshee.

To win you will need "THE LUCK O' THE IRISH"

item.description:
You arrive at Rattlesnake Valley where you build a saloon with your last dollars.
With Rattlesnake City you will discover an exalted life, reconstructed cities, big ranches, old gold mines and a run-down rail way.
You will loot the banks, winning (perhaps) a game of poker and, most of all, you will not save up your bullets.
All means and ways to become the richest man in the west and the mayor of Rattlesnake City are welcome...

The game material consists of:
• The board that shows the valley, some ruins and the rail way
• 1 740 000 $ (in 120 bills)
• 90 bullets (in 54 cards)
• Cowboys, Mexicans, beautiful women, whiskey, tar and feathers, a set of poker cards
• Saloons, banks, mines, schools, hotels, general stores, sheriff, railway stations, churches, cemeteries and 72 pieces of rails track
• 36 wooden markers, a cloth bag, 2 rules overview and a full rules booklet

Mr. Boneyhead is late for work. He just lives down the road from his office. It'd be all so easy except for the pesky pigeon who has taken such a dislike to him.

As the pigeon you must drive Mr. Boneyhead off the street's end. Use any of the tricks that your cards may allow you or... well... use what nature gave you in the end.

As Mr. Boneyhead you must make it to work period. Use your umbrella and whatever the street offers up to you in order to get there. And if you're of a nasty frame of mind... pluck that pigeon's feathers for him. Take enough from his tail and he'll leave you alone while the other birds laugh at his fashion faux pas.

Pigeon Poop... you're in my sights now.

Zombie Basketball...

Enjoy the horror, the humour and the blood and guts of a game played by brave young men and shambling undead zombies.

Play against a friend or by yourself.

As a zombie team you can recruit new players from the opposing team... your bite is infectious and there is no cure.

As a human team... will your sharpshooter be good enough to keep the zeds off your back when you're going for the layup?

Try the game and claim some fame.

Zombie Basketball... are you man or are you meat?
Solitaire dice game in which you get to throw the dice exactly 30 times. If you are efficient with your early tosses, you can use your saved throws to improve your score.
A two-player Rummy variant where certain discards force cards in the draw deck to be exposed.

Flash is a card game for two to five players. Play is much like Rummy, but the emphasis is on sequences. In fact, the player with the longest sequence at the end of the hand is the only player to score. Melds of three and four of a kind are useful, however; they are immediately replaced by a like number of cards from either the stock or the discard pile.

Crossway is played with a Go set. White's goal is to connect the left and right edges of the board with a contiguous sequence of stones, and Black's goal is to connect the top and bottom edges. Unlike Go, you can connect diagonally, so there are eight directions of connectivity in Crossway.

You can’t crosscut, so if your opponent already has connected two stones diagonally adjacent, you’re not allowed to place a stone that would create two mutually crossing adjacent diagonals.

Draws and ties cannot occur in Crossway.

item.description:
Palisade is played with a Go set. Points available to Player 1 are interspersed with points available to Player 2 in a checkerboard pattern. When you form a loop which surrounds enemy stones, you remove the enemy stones from the board. Neither player may place stones into a loop. A player owns the perimeter of his loop as well as all of the points contained within the loop. When all of the board points, both occupied and unoccupied are owned by the players, the game is concluded and the player who owns the majority of points wins.

Rule sheet:
 http://www.marksteeregames.com/Palisade_rules.pdf

Online Play


 Super Duper Games

From The Intro - What is a BackRound? A BackRound is a word pronounced backwards. For example: the BackRound for 'table' is 'leb-bait'. Some BackRounds are made up of actual words like 'eat-is' (which is the word 'city', pronounced backwards).

The first player to collect 5 cards (if team play you must collect 10 cards) wins the game.

From the Intro - The Winery Game is designed to be played by 2 to 6 players, each representing a different winery. The object is to generate the most profits before eight of the twelve markets are filled to capacity. This is done by buying grapes, bottling them into wine cases and selling the wine to the markets spaced around the board.

Word game which uses 40 octagonal tiles with letters on them. Players draw and play a tile at a time to form words. In addition to forming words by adding to the existing layout, one or more lines of letters can be removed and replaced to form a word as well, although each word may only be scored once throughout the game. Can also be played as a solo challenge.

Although ostensibly about battles between tanks, this game is really an abstract strategy game with some superficial similarities to checkers. The game is played between two players who respectively move their tank pieces on an grid of squares in an effort to trap and destroy the other tanks. While the game has some interesting rules for movement and capture, the components are rather low budget--small cardboard circles for the tanks and a fold out paper map.

This is a football (soccer) trivia game. The game includes a plastic ball with electronics which operates as a timer and a noisemaker. Teams of players compete to answer questions to be the first to score seven goals and win the match. Red and yellow penalty cards can be given to players on the opposing team.

This is a roll and move game using the theme of students attending the very exclusive Eton College in England. Players begin with four "colour cards" representing a different facet of life at Eton - artistic, sporting, social and academic. They must then work their way round a stylised map of the college, getting rid of all their cards to become the winner. A variety of penalties can be imposed for bad behavior, including a "faux pas" for things such as hitting a teacher with a snowball, or allowing one's mother to turn up at school in an embarrassing hat.

The game was invented by an Eton housemaster and his assistant, both old boys of the school themselves.

Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description: This is a solitaire-type game. The playing field is a row of twelve "gold" bars and the playing pieces are miniature bulls and bears. The game involves rolling a die to move and remove the playing pieces from the bars. This was produced as an executive-style game, as all of the pieces and the die are silver plated.

This is a party game which mixes word play with a hunt. The game involves posting the correct letter into the correct post box. The letters and mailboxes have similar spelled or sounding names, which makes the job quickly putting the right letter in the right mailbox more challenging that it would first seem. The winner is the person posting the greatest numbers of letters correctly. The game consists of eight cardboard post boxes and 384 letters.

Sixteen is an original card game for two players, ages 8 and older. It is easy to learn (about 5 minutes) and takes about 15 minutes to play, though players will find themselves wanting to play again and again before they put the deck away.

Each player is dealt three cards. The remaining cards are placed face-down in the middle of the table as the draw pile. The cards are numbered 0-6. There are two of every card, but only one zero card for each suit. There are also two wild cards. Players take turns, picking a card, and then adding a card to a fanned-out, face-up play pile.

There are two ways to win a set: when the face-up cards total 16, or when the last three cards in the win pile are all the same color or number. So, you have to pay a lot of attention to what's in the pile, as well as what's in your hand, as well as make some educated guessing about what could very possibly be in you-know-who's hand. If the play pile goes over 16, a "bust" is declared and the other player gets the win. The player with the most sets when all cards have been played wins the round.

All of this results in some rather delicious strategic implications. The game can become quite competitive, but the elegance of the game, and the element of luck, keep the competition focused, and light-hearted.

The instructions describe four optional play variations, one of which extends the game play to younger children (perhaps as young as 6), but the game plays best with the recommended ages.

This is a soccer game using the team and players of Leeds United. The game focuses on the placement of players on the board and uses a combination of die rolling and card drawing to establish player movement and goal scoring. In addition to winning matches, players also focus on accumulating the largest amount of money.

NRL (the National Rugby League of Australia) present Full On NRL. The object (as in proper rugby) is to score as many tries and conversions as possible, moving your thirteen players around the board using the Direction Dice. Each of the league's 16 teams are represented in the game as you play the Telstra Premiership or just for fun.

Players draw a card and list as many answers as possible in 60 seconds, receiving one point for every answer. Categories are similar to those on Family Feud, such as, "Things you eat raw." Cards offer three levels of difficulty.

Wings for the Baron is a game of designing and manufacturing World War I aeroplanes. It uses cards to represent the various aeroplane technnologies and random events of the period.

The mechanics are simple: each turn, the players secretly choose two actions to perform: Build (to construct factories), Spy (to acquire other players' technologies, Design (to construct a new type of aeroplane), Research (to get more cards), or Bank (to protect assets from inflation). Since selection is simultaneous and the actions are quick to resolve there is very little downtime.

After resolving actions, the players are awarded points based on the quality of their aeroplane design and their industrial capacity; then a War Status card is drawn to randomly affect the progress of the war. The game ends when the war does, so timing and efficiently using your actions are important factors in victory.

The game typically lasts about 30 minutes.

Wings for the Baron is available from the designer at the game's web site. Compared to the playtest version, previously distributed for free, this desktop-published game has rules edited for clarity, ten pages of historical notes, more easily distinguished colors, and fully-illustrated cards.

English translation from the box:

Muntslag are a tense tactical game, where by buying and selling of currencies, the player can create the winning collection.

The first player who has collected a series of currency on the market is the winner. The player builds its series of currency by buying and selling currencies on the market and trading with other players.
Players pop a die and turn a block of the same color shown on the die. The winner is the first to construct a picture of Pop Dog.

Detailed book explaining rules for 80+ dice games and variants. Fully illustrated with odds tables, score sheets, photos, cartoons and playing examples.

Games include

Boss Dice (and variants - including "Bogey's game"), 
Liars Dice (and variants),
Captain Ship and Crew, or Monterey 
Games you Keep Score in - Yacht, Ten Thousand, Crag, Hooligan, and Chicago
Popular Games - Intelligence, Red Dog, Mafia, Aces, and Poker Dice
Games for Children - Drop Dead, Indian Chief, Matterhorn, Racetrack, and Wipe Out
International Favorites - Bardudey (Greece), Shingoro (Japan), Heaven and Nines (China), Mandando (Phillippines), and Dudo (South America)

Educated Guess - Drawing game. Divide everybody up into two teams (there are rules for 3 players). Players alternate as the DRAWER and try to get their team to guess what they are drawing.

Both teams may guess every round. If the DRAWER's team guesses correctly then they move ahead one space. If the opposing team guesses then the DRAWER's team is blocked. There is no time limit for drawing/guessing. If nobody can guess correctly the DRAWER will choose a new 'Type Of' card to draw.

The board is made up of 5 Greek Letter - Pi, Delta, Theta, Sigma and Omega. Depending on which Greek Letter your pawn is on determines the 'Type Of' clue to be drawn.

The first team to the 'Omega' WIN space is the winner.

item.description: A fast-paced family game played with eight, 8-sided dice with similarities to the games Farkel and Fill or Bust! Players strive to roll three or more of a kind or a one, five, or straight. Bonuses and busts help or hinder the player on their way to be the first to score 10,000 points.

Dateline The History Game is an educational historical trivia game. Players compete to provide the correct historical date of events, and then use number tiles to construct that date in a sort of crossword/scrabble type arrangement. The game's components are cards with the history questions on them and cardboard tiles with numbers on them.

"You don't have to be faster than the shark, just faster than your friends!"

Get Bit! is a card game where players are competing to stay alive as the others are being eaten by the shark.

The order of the swimmers is determined by simultaneously playing cards face-down then revealing the values. The number on each player's card determines position in line (higher numbers in front, lower numbers in back), however ties don't move. The swimmer at the back loses a limb to the shark and is flung to the front of the line! The process is repeated until only two swimmers remain on the table. When this happens, the swimmer at the front of the line wins the game!

item.description: This is a space race game consisting of a playing board depicting the flight to the moon, six different coloured plastic space ships, a set of instructions, and a dial with spinner. The first player to reach the moon and then make the return journey to earth is the winner. The game board is marked with a variety of bonuses and hazards that have consequences for the players as their moon probes make the journey.

This game consists of a multi-colored checkerboard and four sets of cardboard counters. The objective of the game is to complete as many squares as possible. The basic way to do this is to fill in all four sides of a square with your counters and then place a fifth counter in the bed of the square so formed.

'Questo' is a question and answer game that traded on the popularity of the then very young Irish television presenter Eamonn Andrews. It consists of a slotted spinning disc that reveals a letter through the slot when it stops, and a pack of 48 question cards. The first player to answer the question on the card correctly with an answer beginning with the letter disclosed is given the card. The winner is the player who has the greatest number of cards at the end of the game.
Eamonn Andrews also presented "What's my line?" and "This is your life", amongst many others in his career.

name.value: The Game of Word Making & Word Taking

item.description:
"The Popular Spelling Game"

This game uses cardboard letter tiles that have the upper case letter on one side and the lower case letter on the other. The game includes rules for using these tiles in 21 different word games, including spelling games, anagram games, scrabble-like games, and hangman-like games.
A children's game which uses the theme of a hoop toss at a carnival. This boxed game includes two rows of cardboard stand-ups featuring toys and items of the period and four rubber rings.

name.value: Charge! or How to Play War Games

item.description:
Originally published in 1967 in Britain, Charge! is one of two foundation texts establishing the modern miniatures war game hobby. Many of those who play miniatures began with this book and almost all existing rules systems can trace their lineage back to this book.

The book is a detailed building up of rules for playing a war game. It contains detailed discussion of the rationale behind these rules, grounding them in military theory and history. The book contains two sets of rules: an elementary set for playing simple games and an advanced set of rules to provide a richer simulation. It also contains one scenario, a mythical 18th century battle, which is played out step by step in the book.

These rules define the "Old School" of war gaming: individually based figures in large units with written orders to sub-commanders, etc. Despite its age, there are groups of gamers who continue to base their encounters on the spirit of this book if not its strict letter.

item.description:
The game consists of a base with eight large plastic tower sections which are built up into a leaning tower. Each tower segment has 16 columns molded on the side and these are aligned before the game starts.

The simplest game consists of rolling two dice to find the tower segment to be rotated and how many columns it is to be rotated, either clockwise or counter-clockwise. The player who causes the tower to collapse loses the game.

In the more advanced version, players may choose which tower segment to rotate and by how much - between 1 and 3 columns - and the player scores 1 point for each column rotation.

In the final version of the game, players chose a tower element for the player on the left to use and all players are involved in constructing the tower before rotation begins.

(Note: The English language rules don't state that you cannot reverse the last move made. This is compulsory to make the game playable. For the simplest game, if the same tower segment is chosen, then it must be rotated in the same direction as the last move. Alternately, you can use a House Rule that states that the towers can only be rotated clockwise.)

item.description:
In Pandemic, several virulent diseases have broken out simultaneously all over the world! The players are disease-fighting specialists whose mission is to treat disease hotspots while researching cures for each of four plagues before they get out of hand.

The game board depicts several major population centers on Earth. On each turn, a player can use up to four actions to travel between cities, treat infected populaces, discover a cure, or build a research station. A deck of cards provides the players with these abilities, but sprinkled throughout this deck are Epidemic! cards that accelerate and intensify the diseases' activity. A second, separate deck of cards controls the "normal" spread of the infections.

Taking a unique role within the team, players must plan their strategy to mesh with their specialists' strengths in order to conquer the diseases. For example, the Operations Expert can build research stations which are needed to find cures for the diseases and which allow for greater mobility between cities; the Scientist needs only four cards of a particular disease to cure it instead of the normal five—but the diseases are spreading quickly and time is running out. If one or more diseases spreads beyond recovery or if too much time elapses, the players all lose. If they cure the four diseases, they all win!

The 2013 edition of Pandemic includes two new characters—the Contingency Planner and the Quarantine Specialist—not available in earlier editions of the game.

Pandemic is the first game in the Pandemic series.

Pandemic: Survival Promos – Crisis Mitigator/Relocation Specialist

item.description:
From the manufacturer:

Sex Drive is the rollicking adult game that challenges sexual know-how, show-how, and tell-how. Starting on the Outer Course, players answer questions or perform Body Shop tasks to show what they know about sex. The goal is to obtain your Sex Driver’s License, move to the Inner Course, and win by collecting certificates of knowledge from all 8 categories. Categories include women’s issues (Keeping A-Breast), men’s issues (Getting A-Head), sexual myths and fables (Trojan Horse Misconceptions), true or false statements (True or Phallus), and unusual or non-traditional practices (Pressed and Repressed). Players landing in the Body Shop will use hands-on skills to sculpt, draw, or act out their sexual knowledge. So grab a hot rod, hit the road and prove how much you know about Sex Drive!
Tactical WWII miniatures rules, emphasising tank on tank combat.

link.value: From Golan to Sinai. The Arab-Israeli Wars 1956-1973

item.description: Tactical Napoleonic rules for miniatures.

name.value: A to Z Rules for Ancient Warfare

item.description:
There is no text on the back of the book. An excerpt from the Author's Notes inside is as follows:

"A to Z Rules For Ancient Warfare is a fast playing set of rules for 25mm and 15mm miniatures. It is compatible with all basing systems, army organizations and army lists. It will enable you to play a game with 300 to 400 figures per side in about four hours.

The heart of the rules is the initiative-impulse movement system, the command control system and the morale system. These are the most critical areas determining the flow of the game. They are also areas of great flexibility and changes can easily be made to meet the requirements of different army compositions or scenarios."

Naval miniatures rules for the Napoleonic period. Single ship to Fleet Actions. Trafalgar fought in 6 hours by 30 players. Single ship engagements last from 10 to 20 minutes. Easy to learn, fast playing.

A brief description from inside the book is as follows: "The A to Z Rules for the American Civil War is the second in series of fast playing rules for 15mm and 25mm miniatures. It is compatible with all basing systems and can be played on a regimental or brigade level. It will enable you to lay a short scenario in three hours or recreate a massive day long battle in brigade scale within five to six days.

The A to Z Rules, the Campaigns of Napoleon 1796-1815, is the fourth in a series od fast playing rules for historical miniatures. It is compatible with all basing systems and can be played on a battalion, regimental, or brigade scale. It will enable you to play a short scenario in three hours or recreate a massive day long battle in brigae scale within five to eight hours. The heart of the rules are the intiative and action allocation systems. Combined with morale variables, these are the most critical areas determinging the flow of the game. They are also areas of great flexibility and changes can be made to recreate local conditions, commander capabilities, or scenario anomalies.
Tactical miniature wargames rules for the Napoleonic period.
Interesting umpired miniatures ruleset based on Colonial campaigns in India in the 19th Century.

Subtitled: or, Too Much for the Mahdi.

Unusual set of umpired miniatures rules depicting late 19th Century Colonial Campaigns in Africa.

In essence, the referee plays the part of the Mahdists while each player takes the part of an individual officer commanding part of a British force in the Sudan. This is done to simulate the asymmetrical nature of Colonial fighting in that region: the British often had an overwhelming advantage in firepower but were travelling through unknown territory and facing enemies of unknown number.
Rules for English Civil War wargames with army lists and campaign system. 2nd Edition is revised and amended.
An introductory book on American Civil Wargames, with miniatures. Full rules set included.
An introductory book on Napoleonic Miniatures Wargames, including basic history and a full set of tactical rules.
Tactical WWII miniatures rules emphasising command and control issues.
Tactical Miniatures rules for the 18th Century period.

Tactical miniatures rule set focusing on the American War of Independence. Rule system adapted from General de Brigade.

Title: British Grenadier! - Gaming the Wars for America 1775-1783

Pages: 80 pages with 4 color pages + 4 pages of card play sheet
Size: A4 format - (21cm x 30cm)
Type: Paperback book
Publisher: Partizan Press
ISBN: 1-85818-535-1

item.description:
From the rulebook's back cover:

"Ge Koku Jo is a fast-paced game of Samurai skirmish. No need for massive armies. No need for memorizing long lists of arcane details. Ge Koku Jo makes building your forces simple and flexible and gets right to the excitement of battle and command. Usable at a variety of scales and sizes, games can be played in under two hours."
